definition[0]: to become warm, or to make someone or something warm
example[0]: With the fire on, the room should soon warm up.
example[1]: Once the weather warms up, you can move the plants outdoors.
example[2]: I turned on the grill to warm it up.
example[3]: Come inside and have a drink. It’ll warm you up.
definition[1]: to heat food, especially food that has already been cooked, so that it is hot enough to eat, or to become hot enough to eat
example[4]: I’ll put the lasagne in the oven to warm it up.
definition[2]: to do gentle physical exercises to prepare your body for dancing, sport etc
definition[3]: if a machine or engine warms up, or if you warm it up, it becomes ready to work properly after being switched on
example[6]: He waited for the photocopier to warm up.
example[7]: He started to warm up the aircraft’s engines.
definition[4]: if a party, election etc warms up, it starts to become enjoyable or interesting, especially because more is happening
example[8]: The race for governor is beginning to warm up.
definition[5]: if musicians, singers, or performers warm up, they practise just before a performance
example[9]: The band had little time to warm up before going on stage.
definition[6]: to perform or speak first at an event, so that the people listening are relaxed or excited before the main singer, speaker etc comes on
example[10]: He warmed up the audience by telling them a few jokes.
example[11]: They warmed up for U2 on one of their early tours.
definition[7]: a set of gentle exercises you do to prepare your body for sport, dancing etc
definition[8]: a warm-up match, game, or race is held to give the sportsmen or players practice before a big event
definition[9]: warm-up exercises are done to prepare your body before playing a sport or dancing
definition[10]: a warm-up jacket is worn to keep you warm when you are doing exercises
definition[11]: a warm-up man or band prepares the people at an event for the main speaker, singer etc by singing, telling jokes etc
